Award.AwardTitle: Processes and Rates of Arc Crust Growth and Differentiation in the Southern Sierra Nevada Crustal Section
Award.AbstractNarration:
The construction of magmatic arcs at subduction zones plays a critical role in the creation of new continental crust on Earth. In particular, a number of different mechanisms in the lower crust (>30 km depth) of arcs are hypothesized to be critical for the formation of felsic continental crust. However the restricted number of locations worldwide where rocks formed at these depths are exposed on the surface is a fundamental limitation to improving our understanding of the chemical and physical controls on these processes and the time scales over which they occur. This proposal aims to evaluate these processes through a detailed study of a relatively little studied exposure of lower crustal rocks in the southernmost Sierra Nevada batholith, combining field observations, major, trace element and isotope geochemistry, and high precision geochronology. The research activities in this project will be integrated with field and analytical experiences for undergraduates while findings will be incorporated into undergraduate courses. Through collaboration with the Tejon Ranch Conservancy, it is planned to help develop outreach programs and education materials for the Tejon Ranch property. These programs include geologic tours of the ranch, and will cover both the basics of plate tectonics and arc magmatism, as well as the geologic history of California. The programs will be available to the general public, and be specifically targeted to public schools serving the primarily underrepresented minority populations in the Tehachapi/Bakersfield region.

The Sierra Nevada Batholith is one of the best-studied examples of continental arc plutonism, but nearly the entire exposed range samples rocks formed at shallow to middle crustal pressures, and as a result our understanding of lower crustal processes in the Sierra Nevada are limited. However, the Sierra Nevada also contains a unique crustal section, exposing a structurally continuous section extending from ~7-37 km depth, and containing a suite of igneous rocks emplaced contemporaneously at ~100 Ma, coinciding with the Late Cretaceous Sierra Nevada magmatic flare-up event. This section provides an ideal location to evaluate different models for lower crustal processes including fractional crystallization and partial melting dominated deep crustal hot zones, cyclic underthrusting and relamination of buoyant material. The combination of structurally continuous and contemporaneously emplaced outcrop will allow us to better characterize these processes and their relevant timescales, and to assess their importance for the generation of felsic continental crust. These findings will have additional important implications for our understanding of the Mesozoic history of the western US, and for validating seismic observations of continental lower crust.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study focused on a crustal section exposed in the southernmost Sierra Nevada Batholith, California. Roughly 100 million years ago, this location was marked by intense volcanism, likely similar to the modern Andes in South America. At this time, igneous rocks cooled and crystallized throughout the crust, from deeper than 30 km to shallower than 10 km. As a result of subsequent tilting and exhumation, these rocks are exposed at the surface today and represent a unique location to study the processes by which new crust is created at subduction zones. We applied a range of geological studies to characterize this crustal section and to identify the major mechanisms by which it formed.

 

A major outcome of this study resulted from new high precision zircon geochronology that showed that the entire crustal section was constructed in <1.5 million years. This is a remarkably short time span that is 3-4 times shorter than comparably sized plutons studied elsewhere in the Sierra Nevada Batholith. In addition to this geochronology, we used hafnium isotopes to show that the majority of the crustal section represents new additions of material derived from mantle melts, with limited incorporation of additional crustal material. These two observations combined require that the crustal section was built during a period of extremely high magma fluxes.

 

The extremely rapid construction of this section creates an effective geologic snapshot of arc crust formation, and allows us to study these processes at all crustal levels in a single location. We showed that there is a distinct transition between the lower crust and the middle and upper crust in the Sierra Nevada. The lower crust is composed of mafic and ultramafic cumulates that preserve dominantly shallow to horizontal magmatic textures, while the middle and upper crust preserves intermediate to felsic tonalites and granodiorites that preserve dominantly steep textures. We showed through this work that this transition is indicative of the crystal fractionation that produces the evolved upper crust, and that the depth of this transition is directly controlled by the temperature gradient within the crust. Finally, we observe that this transition to texture and composition between the upper and lower crust is evocative of the structure of oceanic crust, and suggest that there may be a common mechanism for the formation of oceanic and arc crust.

 

Finally, in addition to the primary focus of this work on the igneous rocks exposed in the crustal section, we also undertook a study of the host rocks into which the igneous rocks were intruded. These rocks are metamorphosed sedimentary rocks. We analyzed the ages of detrital zircon populations separated from these rocks and showed that the protoliths of the metamorphic rocks presently exposed in the lower crust originated on the subducted slab. We showed that these rocks were likely subducted and then relaminated as buoyant diapirs to the base of the arc crust.
